awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Asymmetric Functionalization of 2-D Nanomaterials for Tailored Assemblies
awd_abstract_narration:
PART 1:   NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

In both nature and the synthetic world, particulate materials on the nanoscale play an important role in meeting a wide range of societal needs, from harvesting solar energy to making medicine more efficient to preventing barnacle growth on the underside of ships.  As such, controlling how nanoparticles organize into larger structures could lead to major advances in these areas. The research focus of this CAREER project is to develop an entirely new class of tailored nanomaterials and to assemble them into well defined geometries. Specifically, nanosheets that are only a few atoms thick (graphene oxide) will be functionalized on each face with polymers that have different properties (such as positive and negative charges). These unique structures, called Janus nanosheets, will have properties that are not currently accessible with even current state-of-the art technology and have potential to improve the properties of coatings, medicines, batteries, lubricants, etc. Moreover, this work will help researchers across many fields understand how nanoparticle organization influences and dictates properties so they can be improved. This project will afford interdisciplinary training for the next generation of scientists and engineers, as well as engage elementary school students in science through hands-on demonstrations. The PI will mentor researchers at the high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels of their education, develop an after-school interactive class on hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity for elementary school students, and prepare college students for careers beyond academia through a professional development course for scientists. 


PART 2:   TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The goal of this research is to develop and evaluate a new class of materials for the controlled spatial and temporal organization of nanoparticles in assemblies, as a route to rationally design and optimize form, function, and application. To this end, Janus graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets will be synthesized by the asymmetric functionalization of the two faces of GO with different polymers. The functionality of these Janus GO nanosheets can be tailored to give unique and well-defined hybrid and responsive assemblies. Three specific systems will be exploited to show the properties of these novel materials: 1) Janus GO nanosheets functionalized with phase separating polymers for organization in a defined direction within a polymer host to prepare composite films with directional conductivity, mechanical strength, and gas barrier properties; 2) Janus GO nanosheets functionalized with polymers that can bind to nanoparticles for assembly into well-defined, higher order, and hybrid assemblies with inorganic nanoparticles to improve charge transport, catalysis, and energy storage; and 3) Janus GO nanosheets functionalized with stimuli responsive polymers to reversibly scroll and wrinkle platelets in a responsive manner for dynamic control of gas adsorption and conductivity. The key outcomes of this work will provide the fundamental principles governing structure-property relationships of nanoparticle assemblies such that transformational advances in technological applications can be realized. This work will also provide a framework within which to technically train future scientists at the high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels, as well as engage the interest of elementary students in science through hands-on lessons. Moreover, through this CAREER project at Case Western Reserve University, a professional development course for senior undergraduate and early graduate students will be developed, helping students attain career skills needed for success beyond academia.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. This CAREER award supported the development of methods to control the organization and assembly of 2D nanosheets with each other and with polymers and other nanoparticles to make composite, hybrid structures. Graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets were initially used for this purpose. GO nanosheets can be dispersed in water, then an oil can be added and the system shaken to form an emulsion in which droplets of oil are in the water and the nanosheets are at the oil-water interface. Then, by controlling where polymerization takes place, different composite structures are produced, including solid polymer particles armored with the nanosheets and so-called Janus particles in which each face of the nanosheet has a different chemical functionality. Alternatively, if the polymerization takes place around the nanosheets, then capsules are produced in which the shell contains the polymer and nanosheets and the inner core is whatever the droplet was. For example, capsules with core of ionic liquid could be produced by this route and these capsules were demonstrated to have good properties for the uptake of carbon dioxide gas (CO2). The hybrid materials produced through this work could be used in different applications; in addition to CO2 uptake, they could be used for purifying water, as a feedstock for 3D printing, for thermal energy management, as imaging agents, and for shielding of electromagnetic radiation. This work significantly advanced our understanding on how to use nanosheets to stabilize emulsions and how these systems can be used as a platform to produce new composite structures for specific applications.

In addition to producing different composites, this work supported the development of functionalized nanosheets that can stabilize non-aqueous emulsions (such as oil-oil and oil-ionic liquid emulsions), as well new methods for the modification of GO nanosheets and the development of other nanosheets as particles surfactants (specifically, transition metal oxide and transition metal carbide nanosheets). By using these different nanosheets, new properties can be accessed that cannot be realized with GO. During the course of this work, a new  optical data storage system was also developed. In this can, a quaternary code of 0, 1, 2, 3 is used rather than the normal binary code (0, 1). Two different small molecules were incorporated into a polymer film, and one could be ?written? with heat the other with ultraviolet light. Taken together, work supported by this CAREER award led to 28 peer reviewed publications over the five year funding period and numerous presentations at scientific conferences.

Broader Impacts. This work has produced new composite materials that can be used to address pressing societal needs including purification of water and capture of carbon dioxide, and it also provides new feedstocks for 3D printing which can lead to more rapid adoption of new materials. Support of this grants also helped to train early career researchers who are part of the American scientific workforce. Six PhD students were partially supported (resulting in 4 dissertations to date), as well as twelve undergraduate students and four high school students. These students learned critical skills for success in a variety of disciplines; in addition to laboratory skills, they learned how to design research projects, collect and analyze data, and convey their research results. In addition to supporting early career researchers in scientific research, the PI developed a hands-on demonstration about the difference between hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity, as well as a professional development workshop for graduate students. The hands-on demonstration was shared with 3rd to 5th graders through the Cleveland Public Library after school program (in Cleveland, Ohio). The professional development workshop for graduate students was held at Case Western Reserve University and at Texas A&M University and included presentations and interactive discussions on softer skills, such as time management, handling conflict, and best practices for presentations, that many graduate students do not normally have access to.

 


Last Modified: 05/02/2022
Modified by: Emily B Pentzer
